s.content: Assessment of Child Maltreatment

The primary consequence of child maltreatment is the development of "dysfunction" within the developing child – that is, the "functioning" of abused children is set apart or becomes difficult as a result of having experienced abuse and/or neglect.
Dysfunction may result in immediate impairment, problems in adjusting to the abusive experience, or it may occur as problems later in development.
Therefore, the goal of therapeutic intervention is to address the problems or conflicts within the child's current functioning and/or conflicts that are likely to impair functioning in the future.

Therapists work toward providing abused or neglected children with skills or understanding so that they may be better equipped to interact successfully with others (e.g., family, friends, teachers) and deal with their own thoughts and feelings.

As stated earlier, in order to do this, therapists must understand basic child development (so they can know what is normal or typical) and psychopathology (so they can know what is not normal or typical).
From this base of information, the informed therapist is able to discern which presenting problems are "dysfunctional" and determine if these problems require therapeutic intervention.
Typically, the complexity of cases involving child maltreatment requires multidisciplinary input.
Many communities have established teams to assist in the assessment of child abuse and neglect cases.

These teams may include a pediatrician or other health care provider, a child protective services (CPS) caseworker, a law enforcement officer, an educational psychologist, a child development specialist, a substance abuse specialist, a mental health counselor, and other social service professionals.
In conducting an assessment, the therapist needs to tap the resources of the team.
If a team does not exist, consultation with professionals representing the key disciplines is strongly recommended.
If the therapist and family represent different cultures, it is equally important for the therapist to consult with a professional knowledgeable about the family's culture.
Assessment of the Child Within the Context of His/Her Environment
The maltreatment of children does not occur within a vacuum.
In nearly every case, it is important to assess the functioning, strengths, and needs of a child within several contexts.
Usually the dominant context of the abused child is the child's immediate family.
However, there are also many other contexts or cultures that may have a greater or lesser influence on the abused child depending on the child's age (social networks, extended family, etc.).
In many cases of child maltreatment, therapists have a negative perception of the family (i.e., parents) because of the harm they have caused the child.
The therapist may be angry or think less of the child's parents if they are the source of the child's maltreatment.

However, the therapist should negate neither the importance of the family (from the perspective of the child) nor each family member's ability to contribute important information concerning the child's level of functioning.
Whether or not they are involved in the abuse, parents are usually one of the most informed sources of information about the child's daily functioning and presenting problems.

Similarly, an assessment of the child's functioning within settings such as school, social gatherings, daily after school activities, and day care provide information about the maltreated child from several sources and in several environments.

One benefit of developing a multienvironment, multisource assessment of the child is that patterns of behavior, identified across contexts, increase the validity of the presence of a particular behavior or characteristic.

For example, reports from a parent that a child is frequently belligerent and noncompliant might be supported by reports from his/her teacher that indicate that the child is frequently involved in physical fights with peers, has temper outbursts, and refuses to complete schoolwork.
A valid conclusion that could be drawn from these reports is that this child possesses a relatively stable pattern of oppositional or defiant behavior.
Using multiple sources of information to assess an individual's functioning is not unique to clinical assessment or to child abuse.
80 81 82 The rationale for this approach is fairly simple – in most cases, abused children do not exhibit a uniform pattern of behavior in response to their abuse.
Therefore, by using multiple sources of information to identify dysfunctional patterns of behavior, the child therapist can focus attention on those behaviors that require intervention.
It is important to point out that not all abused children require therapeutic intervention and, when provided, treatment should focus on problems that may impair current or future functioning.
Issues to be Considered in Assessment
As previously described, individual development progresses in an orderly manner that is common to all humans.
83 Additionally, there is a continuity to each person's development, which, although it may be subject to periodic changes or fluctuations, is present throughout his/her childhood.

Sroufe and Rutter argue that "disordered behavior does not simply spring forth without connection to previous quality of adaptation..." and that "change, as well as continuity, is lawful and, therefore, reflective of coherent development."

84 When applying these concepts to child maltreatment, it becomes apparent that the clinical assessment of a child must examine the child and the presenting problem (consequences of abuse) in relation to the child's developmental status and capacity for adaptation.
This approach is essential for developing treatment plans appropriate for a specific child's developmental needs.

For example, it would be foolish to implement a verbal mode of therapy for a preverbal child, and conversely, it would be just as ineffective to attempt parent training (traditional child discipline skills as might be effective with a preschool-age child) for the parents of a 16-year-old client.
As a child changes and adapts throughout his/her childhood, the manner in which he/she expresses dysfunctional or distressing behavior also changes.
85 Therefore, the process of identifying psychopathology throughout childhood must be specific to the developmental status of the child.
Thus, the therapist must possess a broad knowledge of child development (to understand normal and abnormal behavior throughout childhood).
Most published child clinical measures report age limitations for administration and clinical interpretation, and many offer age-specific scores.
The most common examples are measures that assess a characteristic that is expected to change throughout childhood.
intelligence/development assessments (e.g., Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children or Wechsler Intelligence Scales for Children–III);
adaptive behavior measures [e.g., Denver Developmental Screening Test or Vineland Adaptive Behaviors Scales (VABS)]; and
behavioral checklists [e.g., Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)].
Thus, the clinician may erroneously administer an assessment measure to a child who does not have the intellectual or emotional capabilities to accurately report about him/herself.
For example, a child's ability to provide information on self-esteem is inconsistent until the child is between the ages of 7 or 8.
86 Before age 7, the child's developing self-esteem makes qualitative changes, and the child's ability to provide such an internalized evaluation is inconsistent.
It is suggested that the validity and reliability of a child's report of internal states (e.g., feelings, thoughts, perceptions) does not become stable until the child is between 6 to 8 years of age.
Ethnicity and Socioeconomic Status
In general, the therapist should exercise caution when assessing children and families belonging to a different cultural, ethnic, and/or socioeconomic group.

For example, it may be easy to interpret quiet and withdrawn behaviors on the part of a client as passivity and/or dependency when, in fact, the origins of the behavior may stem from culturally derived beliefs about polite and respectful interactions with perceived authority.
In part, this may mean that the assessment instruments are not well suited for populations that are different from the majority population.

As a result of socioeconomic, cultural, and familial factors as well as association with traditional beliefs and a limited awareness of existing mental health systems, different ethnic groups may encourage or discourage a specific form of child behavior.
Thus, ethnically diverse children may exhibit ethnically diverse behavior.

By failing to be culturally sensitive to the specific behaviors exhibited by a specific ethnic group (or child of a specific cultural heritage), the clinician may erroneously identify the presence of a problem when one does not exist.
For example, a clinician may be very concerned about the sexual behavior (and possibly marriage) of a young adolescent Laotian or Thai girl.
However, within this girl's culture, early marriages may be culturally appropriate and expected with social stigma attached to a girl who has not become married during her adolescence.

Conversely, a child of a specific cultural group may be experiencing significant distress and exhibiting this distress in a culturally acceptable manner, but the clinician may fail to acknowledge or identify this distress because of his/her lack of knowledge about the cultural group.

Assessing children and families who are not a part of the majority culture without regard to their ethnic, cultural, and/or socioeconomic distinctions may result in significantly flawed information and, in turn, result in decision making and case management based on flawed information.

There have been several attempts on the part of test developers to be sensitive to children of diverse cultural and ethnic backgrounds and, in fact, a few standardized measures have developed alternative scoring and norms specifically for different subgroups.

Examples of these scoring techniques include the addition of sociocultural percentile ranking for the Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children and supplementary norms for emotionally disturbed children on the VABS.
The VABS also has supplemental norms for hearing-impaired children.
Some researchers have developed translated versions of commonly used instruments, while other have developed ethnic-specific norms for these same groups.

88 Finally, a few assessments have been developed to specifically address the unique characteristics and qualities of different subgroups [e.g., alternative means of assessment such as the System of Multicultural Pluralistic Assessment (SOMPA) and the Black Intelligence Test for Cultural Homogeneity.]
89 90 Although there have been many efforts to make the assessment of children more ethnically and culturally sensitive, these tools have yet to demonstrate reasonable validity and reliability.
Social Desirability and Reporting Bias
When acquiring assessment information from any source, it is always important to attempt to explore and understand potential bias in the reporting of the data about a client.
91 This phenomenon also has been reported and investigated in clinical research involving children.

This is often described as a "honeymoon phase" – the child is not yet comfortable within the therapeutic relationship and exerts control over his/her "typical" behavior to present him or herself as "likeable" or "pleasing."

Furthermore, although parents may be good reporters of behaviors and events concerning their child (e.g., fights, bullying, being suspended from school), they may not be as accurate about less tangible characteristics (e.g., sadness, anxiety, fears).

Therefore, a parent may evaluate his/her child on the basis of significant or major events (e.g., noncompliance, chronic fighting) rather than present a more comprehensive representation of the child.
Finally, although children usually demonstrate a consistent pattern of behavior, some children respond well in some environments and less well in other environments.

For example, a child can be cooperative and compliant within the daily routine and structure of the classroom environment, but he/she has chronic problems in less structured environments (e.g., playground, home, neighborhood play).
In circumstances such as these, a teacher may report that a child has no problem in completing schoolwork, getting along with peers, or in relating to adults.
Because professional roles often overlap and provide similar or the same services, these distinctions are often difficult to make.

Law enforcement officers may interview the child to determine if the offender should be arrested; attorneys may interview a child to determine whether to prosecute a case; child welfare caseworkers may interview a child to determine whether the child's safety in the home is at risk; a psychologist may interview a child for an assessment; and a therapist may interview a child to begin to understand the child's perspective about the abuse and to support the child's resilient responses.

The management of each case requires establishing and maintaining open communication among professionals to minimize the duplication of services, obtain complete assessment information, and develop treatment and case management plans.
Use of Standardized Measures
During the past 30 years, there has been consistent debate regarding the benefits of the clinician's judgment versus the use of actuarial methods.
93 94 Using standardized assessment techniques and combining these techniques with sound judgment based on clinical experience and training has been shown to be the best approach.
Therefore, the clinician must become familiar with assessment instruments, their development, applicability to different populations, psychometric properties, and limitations.
Usually, it is sound clinical practice for a clinician to use an unfamiliar measure under the supervision of some other professional who is familiar with its use.

By using a new or unfamiliar measure in conjunction with a familiar or more well-known measure, the clinician can begin to develop an understanding of the new instruments in relation to a well-understood instrument.
Multiaxial Assessment
Multiaxial assessment is comprised of information from many different sources including the following:
direct assessment of the child,
clinical interviews with the child,
family assessment,
The Child Depression Inventory is designed to acquire information directly from the child by inquiring about the presence and severity of most of the childhood depression symptoms.

The Thematic Apperception Test (TAT), for 5- to 18-year-olds, developed by Murray, and the parallel Children's Apperception Test (CAT), developed by Bellack, are designed to reflect internal states or constructs of the child.
In addition to the overall objective of providing information about intellectual functioning, intelligence tests offer a means of assessing other areas of the child's functioning.
other professionals' reports, and
physical assessment.
With the exception of physical assessment (typically conducted by trained medical personnel), discussion follows on all of these sources.
Assessment Information from Children
Perhaps the most important single source of information comes from the abused or neglected child.
Often, information about the child's level of functioning, skills, needs, and/or problems can be acquired simply by asking or observing the child.
There are several standardized instruments that can be administered directly to the child and interpreted by the trained clinician.

Although obtaining assessment information directly from the child may present problems concerning validity and reliability (especially with younger children), the experienced clinician can still acquire much information from this process, especially when this information is supplemented by parent, teacher, or other assessment data.
The following is a brief overview of some common techniques and measures.
None of the instruments described in the following sections should be considered exhaustive nor comprehensive.
Rather, they are simply a sample of techniques within several common categories.

The reader is cautioned that the material in this manual represents an overview of issues related to child maltreatment and is in no way meant to replace formal training in social work, psychology, counseling, psychological assessment, or any other discipline.
Behavior Report and/or Observation
A few behavioral/observational and screening measures for the more common childhood disturbances are presented in this section.
It is important to note that the results of a single measure should not form the basis for diagnosis or treatment recommendations.

Several behavioral/observational tools measure such as the Behavioral Avoidance Test, Teacher's Rating Scale, and the Observer's Rating Scale of Anxiety have been found to be reliable and valid measures of child anxiety.

Additionally, there are several child self-report measures that appear to be valuable, including the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, the Children's Manifest Anxiety Inventory, and the General Anxiety Scale for Children.
Depression .
The CBCL and the Personality Inventory for Children assess a variety of symptoms commonly associated with childhood depression.
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) .
One of the most frequently used measures of assessment of ADHD is the Conners Rating Scale, which has been shown to be fairly accurate in discriminating hyperactive from nonhyperactive children.
This measure is typically administered to parents and/or teachers and is often supported through clinical interviews with the child, parent, and teacher.
Casual Observations
Within the therapeutic or assessment setting, one of the more informative sources of information involves direct observation of the child before and after the appointment.

This approach may include observing the child and the parent or caretaker sitting in the waiting room, walking to or from the appointment, interacting with other children and agency personnel (e.g., receptionist, other therapists).
These observations allow the clinician to examine how the child engages with other individuals while not being formally evaluated.
These pseudonatural observations are often informative because they reveal behaviors and actions that the child may conceal or inhibit during the assessment or therapy session.
Projective Assessments

Although empirical research has consistently demonstrated that projective techniques fail to demonstrate an adequate level of reliability and validity, clinicians continue to use these forms of assessment.
Therefore, the question regarding why clinicians continue to use a form of assessment that has consistently proven to yield unreliable or invalid data.
One possible reason is the relative ease of use of these instruments, supported by the ease with which they can be informally interpreted.
Similarly, when using a projective assessment instrument, a clinician may selectively interpret the test materials, adapting them to "fit" the case.

Therefore, after repeated administrations and selective interpretations, a clinician may develop the belief that the projective measure has accurately provided valuable information about several cases and thus, artificially elevate the validity of the projective measure.
Projective assessment techniques offer a unique opportunity to interact with the child in a semistructured format.
These techniques allow the child to direct the conversation by either responding to a stimulus presented by the clinician or to direct the topic through a drawing or action.
Projective Drawings
Each of these forms of assessment centers on providing the child with a basic set of instructions, which is typically kept to a minimum.
The child is provided with paper and a pencil, crayons, or markers.
For example, Hammer suggests requesting the child to draw a house, then a tree, and finally, a person.
95 The house is drawn to elicit or arouse associations with the home or family and consequent familial relationships.
The tree symbolizes life and growth, and is reported to reflect the child's relatively deeper and more unconscious feelings about him/herself.
Finally, the person is reported to represent the self-representation of the child within the family and/or environment.
Other forms of human figure projective assessments include Kinetic Family Drawing and the Draw-A-Person.
98 99 With the TAT, the test administrator shows the child a card with a drawing or photograph and asks the child to tell a story about what he/she thinks is happening in the picture.
The child then creates a story, which is believed to be representative of his/her cognitive-emotional processing.
The TAT has approximately 20 separate pictures or cards, all or some of which may be administered to the child.
The CAT, administered in a similar manner, was designed specifically for children and has themes more common to children.
CAT presents animals in the pictures rather than human representations.
The test administrator gives each card, one at a time, to the child and asks the child what he/she sees in the inkblot.
The child then describes his/her perception while the administrator records the verbatim response.
The child may see a single percept or several connected or unconnected percepts on each card.
After completing this phase, the test administrator then reviews each card again, asking for clarification about how the child perceived each card.
There have been several different scoring systems developed for the Rorschach, with specific scoring for children.
The most popular scoring system has been developed by Exner.
Cognitive Assessments
The overall objective of intelligence testing is to provide an index of a child's intellectual functioning in relation to other children within his/her age group.
Because intelligence is such a significant factor in a child's development, any concern about cognitive deficits should be identified and addressed.
The child's intellectual functioning influences the approach to treatment.
Certainly, not every abused or neglected child should receive an intellectual assessment.
But if limitations in the child's intellectual capacity impair the ability to obtain, process, or retain information acquired from therapy, then alternate therapeutic plans may be necessary.
For example, a child with a significant learning disability and a poor ability to verbally mediate thoughts and ideas is probably not well-suited to a verbal or didactic therapeutic plan.
By providing a structured environment, the evaluator can assess the child's ability to stay on task, follow directions, and change from format to format.

Because most intelligence tests begin with relatively simple items and then become increasingly difficult, the evaluator also has the opportunity to observe the child's response to frustration and failure.
Finally, intelligence tests often use items that require some type of social judgment.

For example, on the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-III (WISC-III), the subtest on comprehension asks questions about how a child might react in certain situations (e.g., "What would you do if you were at the movies and you saw a fire?"
"What would you do if a child, smaller than yourself, tried to fight with you?")
This scale asks the child to provide an underlying rationale for common phenomenon (e.g., "Why should you trust a friend?"
A common criticism of intelligence tests involves their applicability to children of ethnic minorities.
Several studies have demonstrated that intelligence tests are inappropriate and unfair for lower socioeconomic groups and children of ethnic minorities.

Although these biases appear to be relevant to all intelligence tests, some test developers have attempted to minimize this phenomenon by reducing the culturally biased items, decreasing the verbal component of the tests, and providing specific norms for certain ethnic minority groups.
101 Nevertheless, the clinician should be cautious when using intelligence tests with lower socioeconomic groups and children of ethnic minorities.

As a rule, the use of intellectual assessments for clinical purposes is restricted to professionals (psychologists, psychometrists) who have formal training in the application, administration, and interpretation of these assessment tools.
However, some professionals without formal training may attempt to interpret or reinterpret reports of an intellectual assessment.
Obviously, this practice is unethical and belies the underlying rationale for all assessments – the careful and informed use of an assessment measure for specific and appropriate purposes.
Bayley Scales of Infant Development (BSID)
Although the BSID is the most popular measure of infant development, it is only indirectly related to intelligence and has not been shown to be a good predictor of later intelligence for all infants.
However, infants who score very poorly on the BSID have demonstrated significant difficulty in later years.
Wechsler Series of Intelligence Tests for Children

These intelligence assessment instruments, the Primary Preschool Scale of Intelligence-Revised (WPPSI-R) for 3- to 6-year-olds and the WISC-III for 6- to 15-year-olds, were developed to yield an overall intelligence score (full-scale IQ) and to provide a means to assess both verbal and performance IQs.

Both of these instruments are administered directly to the child by a trained clinician (typically a psychologist, educational psychologist, psychometrist) and yield three scores – a performance IQ, a verbal IQ, and a full-scale IQ.
Both the performance and verbal IQs consist of several subtests that assess different cognitive abilities.
The full-scale IQ is a combination of the performance and verbal scores.
(All three scores have a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15.)
Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children (K-ABC)

The K-ABC, for 3- to 12-year-olds, was developed to more accurately reflect research in the area of children's intelligence, which suggested that an individual's intelligence was better assessed by examined mental processes than by verbal and performance domains.
In addition, the K-ABC yields an achievement score, based on six school-related subtests.
The K-ABC also provides supplemental norms for hearing-impaired children and children from different sociocultural backgrounds.
Clinical Interviews
The clinical interview is a common method for obtaining information directly from a child.

The interview may take on a variety of forms, including a nondirected play session, an open-ended dialogue, a verbal account of client history and presenting problems, and a structured psychiatric diagnostic interview.
Perhaps most frequently, a clinician may combine several of these interview approaches in developing a broad base of information (both observational and reported) concerning the child.

However, parents appear to be better at reporting external, behaviorally manifested problems about their children (e.g., aggression, crying) than they are at reporting problems that are more intangible (e.g., low mood, anxiety, grief).
Assessment Information from Parents
One of the most common sources of information about a child is the child's parents or caretakers.
Usually, parents have the most consistent and reliable perspective of their child and are invested in providing valuable information.

For a comprehensive assessment of a child, it is essential to interview each parent and obtain information about the child's functioning in a variety of settings (e.g., home, neighborhood, school, or church).
Parents, like all reporters, are subject to bias in providing information about their child.
Therefore, it is important to assess both the information provided by a parent and the parent's ability to provide valid and reliable information.
Several standardized child assessment measures have been developed for parents to complete concerning their child.
Parents not only have an important influence on their children; children also have a significant influence on their parents.
For example, when provided with a small house and a family of play figures, most children will begin to manipulate these toys in a manner that reflects their perception of family interaction.
The VABS is usually administered within a structured interview format, asking parents about behaviors of their children.
One of the most essential elements in understanding a child is the assessment of his/her family.
It is important for clinicians to remember that as children develop within their family system, the family as a whole goes through a process of changing and adapting.
Without a clear understanding of the problems, capacities, and abilities of the entire family, it is difficult to determine a treatment plan for the child.
The general purpose of a family assessment should be to acquire a more complete understanding of the child within the environment in which he/she lives.

Additionally, because one of the primary outcomes of the assessment process is the identification of problems, strengths and needs, and capacities, the parents (and family as a whole) reflect these characteristics for the child.

Modules for the professional preparation of teaching assistants in foreign languages.
These alternative assessments offer great possibilities to second language (L2) classrooms in Newfoundland and Labrador (NL).
Emphasis on grades can shift to student progress so students do not become focused solely on ability.
Students and teachers can learn through their mistakes.
Portfolios can also enhance students� metacognitive skills in second language acquisition.
Thus, once the challenges of planning and implementing portfolios are overcome, the benefits of this type of alternative assessment in L2 instruction can be great.
Self Assesment
Recently, there has been a move towards increased authenticity and communication in second language teaching (Saito, 2003).
In accordance with this trend, the use of self-assessment in French second language classrooms has become increasingly popular (Canning & Coombe, 2002).

This development is in line with constructivist theories of language acquisition which hold that language teaching is most effective when it is learner-centered and the student actively participates in and realistically evaluates their own learning (Shepard, 2000).
Self assessment requires students to reflect upon their learning and make judgments about the knowledge and skills they have acquired in the target language.
In this way, students are able to monitor their own progress and set goals for future learning (National Capital Language Resource Center, 2004).
Some educators have been reluctant to incorporate self assessment into their second language teaching for various reasons (Dickinson, 1987).

However, because of its many advantages, this type of assessment, if used properly, can be a valuable tool for teachers and students in French language classrooms (Januleviciene & Kavaliauskiene, 2007).
Self assessment is advantageous first and foremost because it facilitates learning.
By assessing the quality of their French language skills, students will become more aware of the learning process (Blue, 1994).
In other words, self assessment activities call upon students to think about their own second language learning and determine both their strengths and difficulties.
Students can then use this information to set future language learning goals.
This makes the learning process more relevant and personal for students (Harris, 1997).
In addition, self assessment gives learners insight into the various methods of evaluation which further enhances their understanding of the learning process (Oscarsson, 1989).
Another positive result of using self assessment in the second language learning environment is that it encourages students to become autonomous learners (Blanche & Merino, 1989).

Because it compels students to monitor their progress and make choices about their own language goals, this form of assessment helps learners become more independent and responsible for their own learning (Xin & Qiqong, 2005).
For teachers with a large number of pupils, this has special significance since it is difficult to check with each individual student daily (Harris, 1997).

Instead, the teacher acts in a supportive capacity and students become more independent by learning to filter through the feedback they receive and utilize only that which will enhance their learning of French (Dragemark, n.d.).
The inclusion of self assessment can also serve to increase motivation in the second language learning environment (Blanche & Merino, 1989).
Research shows that for some students, motivation to learn French can be quite minimal (Carr & Pauwels, 2006).
In order for students to be stimulated, they must perceive that they are making progress and self assessment facilitates this (Harris, 1997).
Students will feel more positive about learning the target language since self assessment emphasizes the learner�s capabilities as opposed to what they do not know.
This strategy allows students to feel successful, which in turn keeps them highly motivated (Klein, 2007).
A further benefit of using self assessment is that it provides students with important skills that will benefit future learning (Xin & Qiqong, 2005).
Skills such as organizing, planning, analyzing, goal-setting, and communicating are extremely valuable no matter what the subject matter or skill to be learned (Dickenson & Carver, 1980).
Self-appraising also necessitates students using a plethora of learning strategies and higher order thinking.
These techniques and thinking skills can be carried over to further language learning or to other subjects entirely (Chamot & O�Malley, 1994).
Although there are many benefits to using self-assessment in French language instruction, many teachers are still somewhat hesitant to use this approach in their classrooms (Todd, 2002).
Some educators assert that self assessment results are unreliable since students may �cheat� and produce insincere results (Xin & Qiqong, 2005).
However, the act of cheating in this sense revolves around the notion of displaying the results of one�s learning to others.
When participating in self assessment, a student�s results are purely for their own benefit and information.
In this sense, �cheating� offers no genuine advantage (Dickinson, 1987).
Another reason educators feel self-assessment is unreliable is they suspect students will have a tendency to either over-estimate or under-estimate their abilities.
In other words, they are not capable of providing an accurate evaluation of their progress (McNamara & Deane, 1995).
This concern can be addressed by ensuring that the proper care is taken to gradually introduce self-assessment and its techniques to learners (Blanche & Merino).

Strategies for self evaluation and monitoring must be explicitly taught and students need to be made aware of the many ways in which this method of assessment can benefit their learning (Resource #6).
What�s more, common criteria for making realistic judgments must be established and clearly communicated to students (Blanche & Merino, 1989).
In this way, teachers can improve the validity of self-assessment.
Yet another barrier to the use of self-assessment practices in the second language classroom is related to the unwillingness of some educators to relinquish control of assessment (Blue 1988).
The philosophy of self assessment calls upon students to direct their own learning and make decisions about their progress and goal-setting (Harris, 1997).
In accordance with this, the teacher must move from the role of leader to that of facilitator (Dragemark, n.d.).

Although this adjustment may cause some uncertainty at first, appropriate professional development opportunities for educators can serve to prepare teachers for increased learner autonomy and help then adopt a more learner-centered approach (Oscarsson, 1989).
One final apprehension teachers have about the use of self-assessment in the second language classroom is that it is too subjective to be used for evaluation (Todd, 2002).
By using a combination of external and self-assessment, this concern can be alleviated (Dickenson, 1987).
Mueller (2006) uses the analogy of the traditional written and road test required to obtain a driver's license to demonstrate the rationale behind using both types of assessment.
By incorporating traditional and alternative assessment, teachers have opportunities for evaluation and students can still reap the benefits that come with self-assessment.
More and more, teachers are implementing self assessment practices in their French language classrooms (Harris, 1997).
Some educators have expressed various concerns about the use of this type of assessment (Blue, 1988).
However, these issues can be sufficiently addressed so that the inclusion of self-assessment in second language learning can benefit both teachers and students.

First and foremost, great care should be taken in explaining and practicing the techniques for self-assessment and its use should be gradual so ensure all students are comfortable and well-adjusted (Tedick & Klee, 1998).
To precipitate success, teachers must be properly in-serviced on the topic of self assessment so they become more at ease with the notion of learner autonomy (Oscarsson, 1989).

As well, it is important for teacher to strike a balance between the use of self assessment and more traditional forms of assessment to make certain they have appropriate evaluation for each student at the end of a course (Mueller, 2006).
By effectively incorporating self assessment into classroom activities on a regular basis, teachers are giving students the tools necessary to become better French language learners.
Although a candidate may do well on one section or the other, it is the individual who performs well on both that is actually the best driver.

Alternative or authentic assessment offers a unique portrait of student learning which traditional means cannot represent.
Alternative assessment breaks away from the traditional method of testing and instead, gives control of learning back to the student.
This method of assessment encourages collaborative learning so that past performance and future goals are reflected upon by both teacher and student in an ongoing process (Kohonen, 1999).
There are a variety of tasks that are evaluated by authentic assessment; those that emphasize the �real-life communicative meaningfulness of evaluation� (Kohonen, 1999, p. 6).
These types of assessments involve tasks that are worthwhile and part of the curriculum.
Observation and feedback are the driving forces behind this means of assessment that when applied consistently, provide a thorough and purposeful learning situation (Yoshida, 2001).
These are interactive forms of assessment that are particularly well-suited for use in a second language learning classroom.
Even though research favours alternative methods of assessment particularly in the context of language learning, there is still some hesitancy to implement these forms of evaluation.
One issue that arises when using alternative assessment is the reliability of such measurement.
To address the issue of reliability with alternative assessments, stakeholders in education such as parents, teachers and students should be educated about the holistic value in these assessments.
Unlike traditional assessments, portfolios can be designed to measure any skill, process or content-area knowledge of a student by including a wide range of student projects.
Because of this inclusive process, assessment will provide an authentic description of students� performances (Gomez, 2000).

According to Yoshida (2001) �... in order for an assessment to be authentic, it has to be authentic in the students� world of learning the language, that is, their classroom� (p. 7) In the communicative language learning classroom, speaking in L2 is a meaningful task and through oral portfolios this skill can be assessed and built upon by the students themselves.
This allows the teacher to take on a role of facilitator more than director which frees up more time for assessment.
Alternative assessments are worthy of further investigation in any classroom.
In recommending portfolios as an alternative measure, it is important to keep in mind that students need to be informed of the criteria and scoring rubric used.
Parents need to be involved in this form of assessment in order for it to be successful also.

Portfolios focus on higher learning and critical thinking skills.

In the second language classroom these assessments provide excellent insight into the learning process for both students and teachers.
The results are tangible in instruction and motivation (Sweet, 1993).

A traditional behaviorist, teacher-centered approach to L2 teaching and learning has been replaced with a socio-cognitive approach where the learner�s role is redefined and greater attention is focused on the learning process.
This evolution of L2 methodologies has required that assessment practices evolve as well.

Teaching in today�s society requires changing our learning goals for students so that our methodologies not only include the necessary skills and knowledge for success but also reflect an understanding of how students learn (Bond, 1995).
Alternative assessments are used in L2 classrooms to complement these new methodologies and to enhance their learner-centered nature.
They are ongoing processes that involve both the student and teacher making judgments about the student�s progress in language, using non-conventional strategies (Hancock, 1994).

Since assessment practices should align with instructional methodologies, alternative assessment in a learner-centered pedagogy should be based on the idea that students can learn to evaluate their own learning by reflecting on both their linguistic development and their learning processes (Tedick & Klee, 1998; NCLRC, 2004).

Self-assessment is a form of alternative assessment that encourages this type of autonomous language learning by engaging students in deliberate monitoring and reflection of their progress (NCLRC, 2004; Dragemark, n.d.; Harris, 1997; Srimavin & Darasawang, 2004).

A communicative-based program such as Intensive Core French (ICF) helps build the personal capacity of students by encouraging this responsibility and autonomous behavior through a transdisciplinary approach to L2 education.
Self-assessment encourages learner-centered autonomous language learning.

Learner-centered instruction promotes learner autonomy because its primary goal is to increase students� participation in the learning process by helping them establish learning and self-improvement goals, choosing effective learning methods and strategies, and becoming involved in self and peer assessment (Tedick & Klee, 1998).
This involvement in the learning process helps learners to begin to understand what it means to learn a language autonomously (Brown & Hudson, 1998).

Self-assessment is one tool that educators can use to help students see their learning in personal terms instead of relying on teachers for judgment and extrinsic motivation (Harris, 1997; Dragemark, n.d.; Jacobs & Farrell, 2001).
Students who use self-assessment realize the distinction between competence and performance.
They tend to focus on process rather than product which encourages them to develop their own purposes for learning (Jacobs & Farrell, 2001).
Self-assessments help students to be aware of their strengths and weaknesses so that they know where to direct their efforts in the future (Blue, 1994; Tedick & Klee, 1998).
Finally, self-assessments produce learners who are more active, focused and independent which is a fundamental part of the learning process.
ICF with its foundation in learner-centered communicative language teaching is an ideal setting for self-assessment.
Self-assessment enables learners to make informed decisions about how their learning should progress (Jacobs & Farrell, 2001).

This newfound independence and self-reliance can substantially increase L2 learners� motivation to learn the target language (Brown & Hudson, 1998) By engaging in self-assessments, L2 students become more aware of their communication and learning strategies and they begin to appreciate their capabilities even more.
According to Blue (1994) this helps build a positive self-image, which in turn increases self-confidence.
Self-assessments provide students with periodic opportunities to assess not only their performance but their personal learning goals as well.
According to the NCLRC (2004) when learners feel that they have self-defined, relevant learning goals their motivation to learn increases.

Hence, as learners become more autonomous and confident in their abilities in the target language, it is important that self-assessment practices be built in to sustain motivation to reach higher proficiency levels in the L2 (Blue, 1994).
This is especially important in ICF where effective use of time is so critical.
Self-assessments provide students and teachers with valuable information about learning.
Teachers who implement and use self-assessment gain a profound insight into the abilities and progress of their students (Coombe & Canning, 2002).
This insight can be used to assist students in areas of perceived weakness or to address any issues that may arise concerning course content or instruction.
Moreover, self-assessments can help teachers align their instruction and assessment (Tedick & Klee, 1998).
However, self-assessment is not meant to replace teacher assessment but enrich it by providing links between the teacher and the student.

Hancock (1994) asserts that alternative assessments, such as self-assessment will provide teachers with a wider range of evidence on which to judge whether students are becoming competent, purposeful language users.
These benefits promote the use of self-assessment as a legitimate tool in the L2 classroom.
Self-assessments, however, are not without their criticisms.
Many critics question students� ability to provide meaningful information about their communicative abilities (LeBlanc & Painchaud, 1985).

It is also believed that learners may find it difficult to be objective about their own language level and may not have the necessary experience to make judgments about their own performance (Blue, 1994).
For instance, in ICF, it is questionable whether or not Grade Six students will be able to effectively use self-assessments to monitor their progress.

Harris (1997) asserts that younger students need more guided questionnaires and simpler rating scales but that they may be in fact less resistant to the concept, making the introduction of self-assessments more feasible.
The ability to self-assess is not inherent to most learners.
Students must be taught strategies for self-monitoring and self-assessment in order to ensure validity of its use (Tedick & Klee, 1998).
Opportunities for self-assessment help learners become autonomous and should be gradually introduced (Tedick & Klee, 1998).
It is also important that learners have regular opportunities to assess their performance (Coombe, 2002).
Since self-assessments are largely subjective, the issue of their reliability may be called into question as well.
Blue (as cited in Harris, 1997) suggests that self-assessment has �serious limitations as a method of obtaining an accurate assessment of language proficiency� (p.12).

However, as traditional teacher-centered methodologies fall by the wayside, new, interactive, learner-centered methodologies and assessments that involve learners in the learning process can only enhance L2 instruction.
In conclusion, self-assessment is one method of alternative assessment that can be successfully introduced into a communicative-based program such as ICF.
Despite the young age of the students, self-assessment practices can help teach learners to become more independent and take a more active role in the learning process.
The ICF program provides many opportunities for these students to increase their motivation by using self-assessments to become autonomous language learners.
Self-assessments can assist in this process by making students aware of their communicative abilities through reflection.
Implementing self-assessment into the curriculum requires teachers to instruct students on how to self-assess through modeling.
This process should be gradually introduced and used with other forms of assessment.
Furthermore, teachers should provide constant formative feedback in the beginning stages, as this is a crucial factor in ensuring the reliability of self-assessments for future use (Coombe, 2002).
Blue (1994) suggests that if learners are to become more proficient in self-assessment they need plenty of practice.
The use of self-assessment in communicative L2 classrooms can enhance and enrich students� experiences by allowing them to monitor their progress and become more autonomous.
This self-knowledge is powerful in that it can help learners see learning as a lifelong process (Jacobs & Farrell, 2001).

Many of these students are learning to master the most basic skills of the English language and, therefore, measures of their true performance, to be effective, must allow students to showcase their strengths in a meaningful way within the context of their daily activities (Hamayan, 1995; NCLRC, 2003, 2004; Huerta-Macias, 1995; Wilde 2006).
Why use assessment portfolios with young ELLs?

Portfolios offer an on-going means of measuring achievement; furthermore, they encourage the teacher to take a more participative leadership style and thus enable more student-centered practices in the classroom.
Issues of validity and reliability; significant expenditure of money and time; and adequate teacher and student training appear predominantly in my research.

More importantly, the positive benefits of alternative assessment favours the learners since according to Huerta-Macias (1995) teachers incorporate alternative assessments in order to better understand how their students are learning and ultimately gain better insight on how to approach the needs of the learners (par.

As a result, alternative assessment enables instruction to be individualized and students are engaged in their own learning since it focuses �on the process of learning, rather than the product, students� strengths, and the needs of students� (Tannenbaum, 1996, par.1).
In other words, the learning environment becomes a positive collaboration where students construct knowledge.
Moreover, teachers are able to communicate the results of alternative assessment to all stakeholders including parents and administrators.

Alternative assessment promotes students �to think critically, to analyze, and to make inferences� (Bond, 1995, par.1) whereas traditional assessment such as multiple choice tests do not promote these skills.

Many teachers may feel pressured into confining their assessment repertoire with traditional assessment tools while some may not be skilled in using alternative assessments and in order for students to gain critical thinking strategies teachers need to go outside the box and change their original thinking towards assessment (Bond, 1995, par.1).
Because alternative assessment takes into account the whole child and �examine his or her collective abilities� (Funderstanding, 2001, par.
1), teachers are able to identify positive achievements for every child.

Portfolios are a form of alternative assessment which is a collection of students� work over a period of time and provides visible feedback on the growth of a student�s talents and highlights their skills, enabling meaningful reflection and goal-setting.
Consequently, portfolios should be adopted as an alternative assessment tool for second language instruction in a 2-6 French immersion context.
Portfolios or more specifically process portfolios offers many benefits to students since it �documents the stages of learning and provides a progressive record of student growth� (Scherba, n.d.).
As a result, portfolios promote critical thinking, self-evaluation and goal-setting.

As students mature and enter the real-world, they are going to need decision making skills and in order to succeed students need to learn how to be ambitious and set goals in their professional and personal lives.

When second language teachers in a 2-6 French immersion context use portfolios as a means to assess learners in the target language, students are aware of their own progress since their learning is measured by the students� individual abilities.
This provides a way for students to value themselves as learners.
Traditional assessment on the other hand, evaluates a final product rather than examining how they could improve and set goals for the next task when using alternative assessment such as a portfolio.

In other words, traditional assessment has �short-changed the process of learning in favour of the products of learning� (Mueller, 2006, p.2) while portfolios allow students to take ownership of their learning and take in an active role in setting goals which in turn makes learning more meaningful.
As a result, portfolios focus on a collection of student achievement that showcases student growth over time.

As well, students take ownership of their learning as they self-reflect on their performance and determine what they wish to accomplish as a goal for future tasks through the use of reflective journals and thinking logs (Mueller, 2006, p. 5).
Students are able to reflect upon their learning process since this approach �documents all facets or phases of the learning process� (Paulson, et al, 1991, par.

In a second language classroom, effective learning occurs when a method that combines communicative and content based instruction is used since learners in the French immersion setting use language in an engaging manner.

Portfolios have students take an active role in their learning, therefore, students are engaged in learning in a meaningful manner where the focus is to improve on tasks and discover how to improve on future tasks.
The contents of portfolios such as reflections and samples promote the idea to celebrate the achievements and progress of students.
Portfolios allow the opportunities for others, whether it is classmates, other teachers or parents, to observe its content and acknowledge the students� accomplishments.
Students have a sense of pride in their own growth and accomplishments and need to be the ones sharing their work.
As a result, students can take �ownership of the process that led to the growth and achievement� (Mueller, 2006, p.17).

Consequently, students are taking an active role in their learning and are being recognized for their abilities since portfolios �provide a unique vehicle for capturing and communicating student learning� (Mueller, 2006, p. 3).
Reflection becomes part of learning with portfolios since students are encouraged to develop their skills in the target language.
Some may argue that the management of portfolios in a classroom to be extra work put upon the teacher.
Teachers are �required to devote considerable time to planning and administering the assessment as well as interpreting student achievement� (Winking, 1997,par.
23) which can make the process of administering portfolios daunting and ultimately making time constraints the reason teachers choose to disengage in realizing portfolios in the classroom.
Teachers believe that their workload will increase since there are many stages in planning and collecting material.

The fact that not all educators have the required skills and knowledge in implementing this form of alternative assessment in the second language classroom makes implementing portfolios unappealing to classroom teachers.
Many teachers feel overwhelmed when asking �Where do you keep all the stuff?
How do you keep track of it?
Who gets access to it and when?
Should you manage paper or create an electronic portfolio?
Does some work get sent home?
Will it come back?
(Mueller, 2006, p.3).
As a result, teachers are less motivated to initiate portfolio use in the classroom.

Moreover, teachers must develop individualized criteria and this process �can be difficult or unfamiliar at first� (Sewell e. al, n.d.) and if goals are not clearly specified, �the portfolio can be just a miscellaneous collection of artefacts that do not show patterns of growth or achievement� (Sewell e. al, n.d., p.3).

As a result, analyzing and reporting on collected data can be subjective to the classroom teacher as it is �often cited as a concern in this type of assessment� (Bateson, 1994), therefore, the purpose of portfolios is not utilized and does not benefit student learning.
Secondly, the teacher should develop evaluation procedures to ensure proper grading processes.
Teachers who put portfolios into practice �from traditional assessment are advised that it requires a refocusing, not a redoubling of teacher effort� (NCREL, n.d., par.
7), since the tasks that will eventually be put in portfolios are done already in the classroom.
As a result, assessment and instruction �are joined together with curriculum� (NCREL, n.d., par.
7) and teachers are not developing new activities for portfolios.
Consequently, time is not added onto teacher workload, rather it becomes part of the teaching and learning of tasks.

Utilizing alternative assessment in a second language classroom means that students become more �involved in selecting and reflecting on their learning�, therefore, second language teachers are able to better identify whether their students �are becoming competent, purposeful language users� (Hancock, 1994, par.

Integrating portfolios in the 2-6 French immersion contexts uses activities that demonstrate their abilities in the target language instead of focusing on what students are not able to achieve (NCLRC, 2004, par.

As a result, learning in the context of language becomes what is important and allows second language learners to identify that �the point of language learning is communication for meaningful purposes� (NCLRC, 2004, par.
Second language learners need to be involved in real-world tasks that acknowledge the importance of communicative and content based learning.
